course.title: Introduction to Art History and Criticism I

description.div: Survey of the history of art from the earliest times to the end of the Medieval period.

course.title: Introduction to Art History and Criticism II

description.div: Survey of the history of art from the Renaissance period to the present.

prerequisite.div: Good standing in the University Honors Program or by invitation.

notes.div: University Honors Seminar 189H is required of all students in the University Honors Program.

description.div: Topic varies.
Introduction to the art and archaeology of ancient Greece and Italy.
Introduction to the art of the Middle Ages from the Early Christian to Gothic periods.
Development of Italian art and architecture in the fourteenth, fifteenth and sixteenth centuries.

Introduction to the art of the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries in Northern Europe. Major artists studied include Jan van Eyck, Rogier van der Weyden, Hieronymus Bosch, Pieter Bruegel and Albrecht DÃ¼rer.
Art and architecture in Europe from 1550 to 1700.
Survey of Western painting and sculpture from 1750 to present.

Role of the fine arts in creating national identity. How portraiture, genre, history painting, landscape, sculpture, photography, and folk art produced competing definitions of America. Growth of art institutions and patrons, the development of different audiences and how they established and changed expectations for art and artists.

The changes in art resulting from the US's transition to an urban, industrial and cosmopolitan society. Careers and styles of individual artists, along with the impact of European art before and after the 1913 Armory Show. How the intersection of artists, patrons, and audiences supported the formation of new institutions and markets for modern art.
From pre-Columbian through contemporary art.

course.title: Oriental Art: India, Ceylon, Java, Japan

description.div: Survey of the arts of India arranged according to chronological and cultural development, followed by the related arts of Ceylon and Java; similar survey of the arts of Japan down to the present.

course.title: Oriental Art: China, Korea, Southeast Asia

description.div: Survey of the arts of China arranged according to chronological and cultural development, followed by similar surveys of the arts of Korea and Southeast Asia.

notes.div: Art and art history majors must register for a letter grade.

description.div: Participation in archaeological field research projects to learn basic field techniques.
Art and archaeology of ancient Greece from the Bronze Age through the Hellenistic period.
Introduction of the art and archaeology of ancient Italy from the villanovans through the end of the Roman Empire.
Art in Europe from 1100 to 1500; style and iconography in Gothic art including architecture and architectural sculpture.
Introduction to painting, sculpture, and architecture in Italy from the late 13th century to the end of the 15th century.
Introduction to the painting, sculpture, and architecture in Italy from the late 15th to the mid-16th century.

course.title: European Art of the Nineteenth Century

description.div: From Neoclassicism through Post-impressionism.

course.title: European Art of the Twentieth Century

description.div: European art from 1870 to 1945, focusing on the development of the avant-garde, and on the relationship between art and its historical context.

Survey of the architectural traditions of the African continent, from pre-historic times to the present day. Buildings-famous and typical-theories, and approaches that are appropriate to the specific cultural environments.

notes.div: AHIS/MUSC/THEA 388 will not count towards the major or minor in studio art and/or art history.

description.div: Interdisciplinary approach to the enjoyment and understanding of the contemporary (first half of the twentieth century) arts.

notes.div: AHIS/MUNM/THEA 389 will not count toward the major or minor in studio art and/or art history.

description.div: Interdisciplinary approach to the enjoyment and understanding of the contemporary (1945 to the present) arts.

prerequisite.div: Junior standing and permission of department chair.
Junior standing and permission of department chair.
Junior standing and permission of department chair.

description.div: Culminating experience in art history. A comprehensive analysis of the discipline of art history. Builds on material from previous course work. Historiographic and methodological issues.

prerequisite.div: 12 hrs in art history or related disciplines with permission.

description.div: History and development of architectural orders and styles from ancient Greece and Italy.

prerequisite.div: 12 hrs in art history or related disciplines with permission.

description.div: Greek sculpture from the Bronze Age through the Hellenistic periods. Stylistic evolution and classical themes as presented in individual freestanding and architectural sculpture. Techniques, materials, and uses of sculpture.

prerequisite.div: 12 hrs art history or in related disciplines with permission.

description.div: Development of Roman painting from the Etruscans through the Age of Constantine.

prerequisite.div: 12 hrs in art history, including AHIS 318, or in related disciplines with permission.

description.div: Style, iconography, history, and function of painting and prints from ca. 1150 to 1475 in France, Germany, and the Netherlands. Includes manuscript illumination, stained glass, panel painting, woodcuts, and engravings, stressing the development of naturalism before the "Renaissance" in Northern Europe.

prerequisite.div: 12 hrs in art history, or in related disciplines with permission.

description.div: Exploration of the art and architecture of the Italian city in the late middle ages and Renaissance, with particular attention to civic projects and the role of art in defining the identity, and creating the "myths" of that city.

prerequisite.div: 12 hrs in art history, including AHIS 318 or 418, or in related disciplines with permission.

description.div: Art of the Renaissance and Reformation in Germany and the Netherlands. Stresses the influences of Italian Renaissance Art and the impact of the Protestant Reformation from ca. 1475 to 1575.

prerequisite.div: 12 hrs in art history or in related disciplines with permission.

description.div: Painting, sculpture and architecture in Italy from the late sixteenth to the late seventeenth century.

prerequisite.div: 12 hr in art history or in related disciplines with permission.

description.div: French Impressionism and Post-impressionism with consideration of the historical context out of which they emerged. Development of the avant-garde and the changing relationship of the artist to society.

prerequisite.div: 12 hrs in art history, including AHIS 102 and 246.

description.div: Art from 1945 to the present focusing on the development of the avant-garde, the transition from modernism to post-modernism, and the various art world institutions.

prerequisite.div: 12 hrs in art history, including AHIS 102 or 246, and 446/846; or 12 hrs in related disciplines with permission.

description.div: Developments in art since 1970, exploring the various art styles and the relationship of the artists to their audience and to the institutions of the art world.

prerequisite.div: 12 hrs art history including AHIS 251 or 341 or permission.

description.div: 19th Century American art and material culture.

prerequisite.div: 12 hrs art history including AHIS 252 or 346 or permission.

description.div: Early 20th-century American art.

prerequisite.div: 12 hrs in the history of art or in related disciplines with permission.

description.div: Emphasizing the Mesoamerican and Andean traditions.

prerequisite.div: 12 hrs in the history of art or in related disciplines with permission.

description.div: Emphasizing New Spain, the Viceroyalty of Peru, and Brazil.
Introduction to the history of still photography with major emphasis on its development as an art form.
Movements in photography since 1960 with emphasis on the interaction with art theory and criticism.

prerequisite.div: 12 hrs in art history, including AHIS 221, 226, or 231, or in related disciplines with permission.

description.div: Introduction to the history of prints stressing printmaking techniques, i.e., woodcut, engraving, drypoint, etching, and the makers of prints during the first 300 years of printmaking in Europe. Baldung, Goltzius, Bruegel, and Rembrandt. Major technical developments, such as the introduction of printing colored woodcuts, are included.

prerequisite.div: Senior standing and permission of department chair.

notes.div: Art and Art History majors must register for a letter grade.

description.div: Further training in archaeological field research techniques.

course.title: Honors: Special Problems in Art History

prerequisite.div: Candidate for degree with distinction or with high distinction or with highest distinction in the Hixson-Lied College of Fine and Performing Arts.

description.div: Emphasizing the Mesoamerican and Andean traditions.
History of the discipline, with an examination of the various art historical approaches. Development and refinement of specialized research skills appropriate to the field.

course.title: Seminar in Classical Art and Archaeology
Introduction to the Interdisciplinary Study of the Middle Ages

description.div: Methods and state of research in the disciplines--art, music, literature, language, history, philosophy--dealing with the Middle Ages. Assistance in independent reading and research in subjects related to the studentâs own research interests. Taught jointly by faculty members in art, music, theatre, English, history, classics, modern languages, and philosophy.

course.title: Introduction to the Interdisciplinary Study of the Renaissance

description.div: Methods and state of research in the disciplines--art, music, literature, language, history, philosophy--dealing with the Renaissance. Assistance in independent reading and research in subjects related to the studentâs own research interests. Taught jointly by faculty members in art, music, theatre, English, history, classics, modern languages, and philosophy.
